title: Interpretation of Art
description: Targeting at students with no prior knowledge of art history, this course introduces students to methodologies and theories currently used by art historians and curators to analyze and interpret works of art. The course covers a range of themes such as representation, expression, form, style, Formalism, Iconography, Marxism, Gender etc. Using modern and contemporary Chinese art as examples, the course will equip students with transferable and analytic skills, knowledge of modern and contemporary Chinese art, aesthetic sensibility, and theoretical literacy, encouraging them to apply these methods and knowledge to the study of visual art.
outcome: Demonstrate knowledge of the basic approaches and methodologies in art appreciation Understand of key issues of the visual arts in modern and contemporary China Demonstrate facility in research skills and familiarity with primary and secondary sources Demonstrate the ability to analyse critically works of art by adopting appropriate theories and methodologies
syllabus: Part IIntroduction to the language of visual art and formal elements, definition of art, and key concepts related to beauty in Chinese and European arts.Part IIIntroduction to the development of modern and contemporary Chinese art, ranging from the Republican period to the 21st  century, exploring a range of artistic practices, including ink painting, oil painting, sculptures, and installation and covering themes such as modernism, art institutions, and globalisationPart IIIIntroduction to the theories and methodologies currently used by art historians and curators to analyse and interpret works of art, including Formalism, Iconography, Biographical approach, Marxism and the Social history of art, Feminism, and Semiotics.

title: Introduction to Cultural Management
description: Cultural management is frequently perceived as a new terrain both for the acknowledgement of the role of culture in driving economic and social development, and for the dissemination of managerial thought to arrange and plan cultural entities, facilities and services. This course first aims to facilitate students’ understanding of the rising discipline of cultural management, which is embedded in the transformative understanding of culture and the on-going global movement that highlights culture-led development. Second, it introduces the managerial approach to cultural assets, initiates students’ understanding of the relationship between arts management and the market system and government policies, and imparts the preliminary knowledge for the management of the arts. Third, it displays a spectrum of major issues in cultural management, such as cultural policy, cultural organizations and institutions, venue management and event programming, heritage, conservation and cultural tourism and cultural creative industries. The breadth of the discipline as indicated allows students’exposure to the basic cultural management concepts and strategies.
outcome: In terms of knowledge enrichment, students are expected to achieve the understanding of the discipline of cultural management, including its objectives and values, its relationships with the transformative understanding of culture, the on-going global movement that celebrates culture-led development. Other major issues will also be covered. Students are expected to understand preliminarily the operation of art businesses and cultural organizations in connection to market values and government administrative systems. In terms of management training, students will learn practicalities such as cultural managerial principles, planning strategies and basic skills, issues, challenges and limitations specifically for the arts and cultural resources. Discussions are largely based in the local context, supplemented with overseas and Chinese cases, with an awareness of the variances across contexts.
syllabus: Part I. Cultural Management as a New Discipline  This part introduces the historical and disciplinary background of cultural management.   1. Understanding Culture: history and theory The first section presents an introduction to the course. As cultural management is embedded in the discourse of culture, this section explores the concept of culture and highlights the theoretical transition from the anthropological idea of culture as values and practices to the understanding of culture as a capital and resource. The emergence of the cultural economy concept will also be discussed.   2. Understanding the Discipline of Cultural Management  This section discusses the evolution of the discipline of cultural management over the past four decades, that is, from arts management, to cultural administration and management. It introduces the objectives of the discipline; the way that this discipline has been gradually accepted and subsequently widely practiced; and its closely related neighboring disciplines. It also discusses the professional role of cultural managers; their differences from artists and creative workers are highlighted.  3. Cultural Management in the Globalization of Culture-led Development This section examines the discipline of cultural management from the view of the global movement that utilizes culture as a driving force for development. It discusses a set of concepts that emerged in the recent decades, such as creative industries, creative classes, cultural planning, culture-led urban regeneration and creative cities. It provides the historical background for the evolution of these concepts, discusses the issues and challenges that they encounter and their application in various local contexts.   Part II. Managing the Arts Art management is considered a traditional realm of cultural management. This part focuses on the managerial approach to the arts. Section 4 investigates the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and the peculiarities of art management. Sections 5 and 6 introduce preliminarily the management of two major art sectors: performing arts and visual arts. Sections 7 and 8 are concerned with cultural management in the social environment and discuss its connections to art marketing and administration.   4. Managerial Approach to the Arts How to manage the arts? How is art management different from the traditional study of management? This section introduces the managerial approach to the arts. It explains the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and discusses how art management crystallizes the philosophy of both management and the arts. Art management covers four main managerial issues, namely, strategic management and planning, human resources management, finance and accounting and marketing and consumer behavior. The empirical implications of art management’s peculiarities are also discussed.   5. Introduction to Performing Arts Management  Performing arts is one of the major subjects in art management. This section introduces the concept of performing arts and its management. It discusses basic performing arts programming strategies and its relationship with theatres and other performing art venues. Some basic modes of organizing performing arts and performing art agencies are discussed.   6. Introduction to Visual Art Management  Visual art is another major subject in art management. This section introduces the concept of visual art and its management. It discusses various types of visual art spaces and agencies (e.g., museums and art galleries), introduces their similarities and differences in concepts, functions, operational modes, policies and evaluation modes.   7. Art Consumption and Art Marketing This section focuses on the concepts of art consumption and art marketing. It discusses the determinants of artistic values and the processes of creating and diffusing artistic values in the market. It covers the issues of art consumer behaviors, market prices, cultural business branding and positioning and art sponsorship, from both the consumption-and production-oriented perspectives.   8. Cultural Administrative Structure The government plays a significant role in cultural development. This section attempts to investigate government and public administration in cultural affairs, its administrative structure, patronage and state-based arts funding agencies. Some recent tendencies (e.g., corporatization of government entities in cultural affairs administration) will be examined withHong Kong as the major context for study. Cultural administrative structures in China, Taiwan and the U.S. as well as their institutional reforms will also be examined.  Part III. Major Issues in Cultural Management  This part introduces some major issues in the cultural management discipline, including cultural policies, cultural organizations and institutions, cultural venues and events programming, conservation, heritage and cultural tourism, as well as cultural and creative industries. It will introduce students to the concepts, operational principles and their management or planning strategies. Cases from various contexts will be studied.   9. Cultural Policies  This section introduces the definition of cultural policies and the process of cultural policy making. It presents a preliminary discussion regarding the way that cultural policies affect cultural development. Policy issues such as government subsidies, cultural industrialization tendency, government’s promotion of art values and cultural censorship will be addressed. Cultural policies from various contexts will be examined.  10. Cultural Organizations and Institutions This section categorizes art organizations based on their basic operational mechanisms. It models the growth of firms in the cultural field and describes the sequences and stages as well as determining factors. It also discusses the governing structure of cultural organizations (e.g., the board structure and its impact on organizational missions and strategies), cultural funding and patronage, volunteer management and management control systems. A global perspective is introduced for examining the connections between local and international cultural organizations.  11. Cultural Venues and Event Programming This section introduces the concept of cultural venues, facilities and districts as well as events planning and programming. Students will be introduced to the theoretical discussions regarding the role of cultural venues and events in cultural development and their functions in fostering local culture. It also introduces basic principles of and strategies for cultural venue planning and strategies for event programming,including cultural venue administration, public engagement, event promotion as well as public-private partnership.  12. Cultural Tourism and Heritage Management What are cultural tourism and cultural heritage? What is their significance and inter-relationship? This section defines and discusses their roles in culture-led urban regeneration. It also introduces the basic strategies for programming cultural tourism and explains the significance and methods of heritage conservation. The second half of this section introduces an integrative approach to cultural tourism and heritage management in order to develop cultural destinations, using European, American and Australian casesfor study.  13. Cultural and Creative Industries The last section will investigate the theory and practice of cultural and creative industries. It will examine the historical context in which the concepts of cultural and creative economy have arisen, its adoption as public policy from the UK and worldwide and its reception and development in Asia Pacific region. It will look at policies and strategies as proposed and developed by various countries in the region with particular emphasis on China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Singapore and evaluate the development in Hong Kong.

title: Cultural Theories
description: This course provides an introduction to cultural theories which aims to help students understand and conceptualize cultural dynamics. Taking a step by step approach, this course comprises three parts, which will guide students from the general concepts right through to the core thoughts of various schools of cultural theories. It will firstunfold an overall picture and introducethe basic concepts enshrined in the theories. It will then illustrate the developing process of cultural theories by tracing the critical moments and key authors. The final part will discuss a broad range of thoughts that come from Structuralism, Post-structuralism, Marxism, Psychoanalysis, Postmodernism etc., and the social contexts from which they arose. This course is designed especially for cultural management students,integrating cases and practices of cultural industry and popular art.
outcome: Students are expected to understand and explain the key concepts in cultural theory, the evolution of different theories and major schools of thoughts. Students will also understand the relationship between culture and society, the differentiation between high and low culture, and the interplay between cultural traditions and cultural differences and diversities. Open exploration, in-depth observation and creative application of theories will be encouraged and developed.
syllabus: Part I. Basic Concepts in Cultural Theory Part One provides an overview of cultural theory, introducing the discipline of cultural studies, the concept of ‘theory,’and cultural theory.Key concepts in cultural theory, such as ideology, representation, articulation, and texts and readers, will bediscussed.  1.Overview: Cultural Studies and Cultural Theory This introductory section discusses what ‘theory’ means, why we need theory, what cultural theory is and how it works. It also introduces the discipline of cultural studies as well as the definitions of culture from major theoretical perspectives.  2. Culture and Ideology Ideology is a key concept in cultural theory. This section explores the political role of culture in society and discusses the relationship between culture and ideology. It provides five definitions of ideology and shows the way in which ideology works.   3. Representation and Materialism  Much of cultural theoryis dedicated to explaining how meaning is produced symbolically in language. Two important concepts are relevant: representation explores the textual generation of meaning and the modes; materialism is concerned with why meanings are inscribed at the moment of production. This section also discusses how meaning is produced in the interplay betweentext and reader.  4. Subjectivity and Psychoanalysis The concepts of subjectivity and psychoanalysis are introduced in this section. It also introduces the Freudian self, which comprises ‘an ego,’ ‘a superego’ and ‘the unconscious.’ The relationship between these concepts and cultural theory literature is also discussed.  Part II. Evolution of Cultural Theory Part Two illustrates the developing process of cultural theory, discussing key authors and their contributions in the ‘culture and civilization’ tradition and culturalism.   5. The ‘Culture and Civilization’ Tradition Matthew Arnold inaugurates a tradition which places popular culture within the general field of culture, known as the ‘culture and civilization’ tradition. Carrying on this tradition, F.R. Leavis has shaped the understanding of mass civilization and minority culture. This section introduces the ‘culture and civilization’ tradition and its connection to popular art.  6. Culturalism I: Hoggart, Williams and Thompson Culturalism has been the most vigorous, indigenous strand within cultural studies in Britain. Hoggart, Williams and Hall exemplify the critical moments of the evolution of cultural theory. This section will introduce their works and discuss the influence of their thoughts in shaping later theories.   7. Culturalism II: Hall and Whanneland the Popular Arts Hoggart, Williams and Thompson have a major influence on the understanding of the popular arts. Stuart Hall and Paddy Whannel’s thesis, The Popular Arts, will be discussed. This section will examine the categorical difference between high and popular culture, and the characteristics of difference.   Part III. Intellectual Strands of Cultural Theory Part Three introduces major intellectual strands of cultural theories, ranging from Structuralism, Post-structuralism, Marxism, Feminism toPost-modernism.   8. Structuralism: Generating Meaning from Structure Structuralism is a theoretical method of approaching texts and practices.This section will introducethe origin, trajectory of structuralism as well as its principle of analysis. Roland Barthes’s analysis of mythology based on principles of structuralism will be discussed.   9. Post-structuralism: Meaning in Process Post-structuralists reject the idea of deriving meanings from an underlying structure. The ideas and works of Jacques Derrida and Jacques Lacan will be introduced. This section will also discuss the works by Michel Foucault and Edward Said regarding discourse and power.   10. Marxism I: Classical Marxism and Neo-Gramscian Studies  This section will begin with the introduction of a classical Marxist approach to culture, such as its famous ‘base/superstructure’ account of social and historical development, the determinations that influence the production and consumption of popular culture, and the mode of production. Itwill then proceed to discuss Antonio Gramsci and the core concept of hegemony.  11. Marxism II: The Frankfurt School and Cultural Industry The Frankfurt School has been famous for its critical theory that mixes Marxism and psychoanalysis,as well as the term of ‘cultural industry’ that it coined. This section will introduce the basic concepts of the Frankfurt School, the major representative figures and their critique of cultural industry.   12. Feminism and Gender Gender has been an important subject of study since the 1980s. Several issues will be discussed in this section, such as cultural politics and feminist psychoanalysis. Women in popular culture, e.g., films and fictions,will be adopted as cases for study.  13. Postmodernism: Relocating Value in the World of Everyday Experience The development of Postmodern theory became mature with theorization in the work of Jean-Francois Lyotard and has changed the theoretical and the cultural basis of the study of popular culture in its development. This lecture will illustrate the trajectory of postmodernism and focuses on its connection to various arts forms and popular culture.

title: Cultural Policy and Development
description: The course is an introduction to the nature, functions and making of cultural policies. Making references to examples of local and international cultural polices, it studies the relationship between the making of cultural policy and the infrastructure of power, the ideological influences behind the making of cultural policy. It also studies the latest trends in cultural development and its relationship with policy-making, and the impacts on the development of arts and culture, with particular references to the local context. The course also includes a practical aspect of drafting and developing institutional policy as part of the studies in cultural management.
outcome: Students are expected to learn about how cultural policy is composed, its scope and structure, and the ideological components behind it within the context of the infrastructure of power, and to understand the impact of cultural policy in shaping the development of culture. The course also intends to equip students with the skills of drafting institutional cultural policy, which is essential for the development of a cultural institution.
syllabus: 1. General introduction This section gives an introduction to the various definitions of cultural policies, with discussion on its impacts on cultural development and its relationship with the social and political infrastructure.  2. Culture and Power  This section investigates how political, social and economic powers affect the outcome of artistic creation, both in terms of the formal artistic languages and the modes of production and mediation.  3. Historical Background  This section uses examples from Europe and the United States to trace historically how various modes of governance were introduced and study the political expectations and social values hidden behind these policies.  4. Globalization and Cultural policy  In the 21st Century, cultural industry is recognized as an important economic and social force. Large scale cultural projects are implemented all over the world to promote cultural tourism and creative industry. This section takes a critical look at this global trend and reviews its cultural and social impacts.  5. Cultural policy in Hong Kong This section informs students of the infrastructure for cultural development in Hong Kong, studies the history and development of the arts within the governmental structure, and traces the various stages in developing a cultural policy for Hong Kong.  6. Institutional Policy Cultural institutions usually have their own cultural policies to set their visions and objectives for their long term development. This section studies the various types of institutional policy, with an emphasis on helping students to learn to prepare an institutional policy paper.   7. The Ecology of Culture  This section investigates some of the core cultural values in contemporary society, with emphasis on the Hong Kong context. It also introduces an ecological approach to cultural development, and reviews the success and failure of the existing cultural policies within the public and private sectors.  8. Cultural Development and Operation in China  This section studies another model in which cultural development is strongly managed by the government. Taking Shanghai as example, students will study the process of organizing exhibitions in China and ideological thinking behind this bureaucratic system.  9. Language of the Bureaucrats  In Hong Kong, the government has tremendous influence on the ways arts and cultural programmes are implemented. This section investigates how the civil servant culture and the language they apply shape the content of the policy produced, and consequently affect the course of cultural development in Hong Kong. Case study: Culture Heritage Commission  10. West Kowloon Cultural District: Mega Cultural Project Focusing on the development of the West Kowloon Cultural District project, this section reviews the original proposal, public responses, and the subsequent reaction of the government, with the intention to investigate the governmental modes of thinking and strategies in actualizing cultural projects.  11. Alternative Space and Community Action  As a reaction against governmental dominancy in cultural development, different types of alternative cultural institutions and groups are formed. This section investigates the potential and limitation of various types of non-government run organizations. It also studies the strategies of community groups in working with and against the government in fighting for a more nurturing cultural environment. Case study: Hong Kong Arts Development Council, Para site Art Space  12. Cultural Policy and the Future of Cultural Development of Hong Kong  This section looks into the future cultural development of Hong Kong, its relationship with China and other regions, and discussion the problems and possibilities for positive development.  13. Review and Discussion

title: Chinese Archaeology and Food Culture
description: Archaeology reveals many interesting findings about ancient social lives. Food has always been an essential category in human culture. The amount of food surplus determines the strength and social bonding of a society; and rituals are usually revolved around food preparation, presentation, and distribution. In China, a large number of archaeological sites contained remains of food, and occasionally drink. This course picks the representative sites to illustrate what food meant to a society that can be summarized in categories listed below: 1. Consumption of staple food: rice and noodles; 2. Perception of tastes: sweetness and bitterness; 3. Cooking methods: steaming and roasting; 4. Exotic food: what had been imported to China and when? 5. Drinks: tea and wine; 6. Rituals that involved food. This course is suitable for students who have interests in Archaeology but may not have prior knowledge about it. It aims to prepare them for exploring the past of China in the future, either in form of class teaching or self-learning, or both. The course gets students to apply the designs and innovations of ancient China in regards to food and the practice of cooking, dining and rituals to the present.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to:  1) Identify key recent archaeological discoveries of China; 2) Analyze the functions and meanings of archaeological finds in particular contexts;  3) Acquire research techniques in reading primary data; and  4) Think critically about archaeological presentations, such as museum exhibitions, and relevant cultural events
syllabus: Part I: Discoveries of food and drinks  1. Introduction: Food, climate, and geography  Natural environment determines the type of staple food in different regions. This introductory lecture explains the basics of fauna archaeology and the various devices available to identify food and drinks ingredients.  Reading:  Liu Li and Chen Xingcan. ‘Neolithization: sedentism and food production in the Early Neolithic (7000—5000 BC)’ (chapter 5), The Archaeology of China: From the Late Paleolithic to the Early Bronze Age. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 123—168.  2. Rice and Hemudu Culture (5500—3300 BC) Carbonated rice husk was found in a number of early and mid-Neolithic sites in China. All evidence points to the origins in the mid and lower Yangtze River valley. This lecture uses Hemudu site as an example. The excavations over the last decades revealed many earliest finds in this Neolithic culture: rice paddy field, musical instruments, fortune-telling devices, etc.  Reading: a. 《河姆渡: 新石器考古遺址發掘報告》北京 : 文物出版社 2003 b. 賀聖達，《稻米之路:中國與東南亞稻作業的起源和發展》,《東方論壇》2013年05期，第23-30頁。  3. Noodles and the site of Lajia of Qijia Culture (c.2500—c.2000 BC) Lajia of Qinghai province is the Chinese version of Pompeii. It was a small town destroyed and covered by dust right after an earthquake. There preserved a bow of unfinished noodles made of millet (小米) and husk millet (黍米). The noodles still carried a tinge of the original yellowish colour. This lecture begins with the finds at Lajia and refers to many other archaeological evidence of noodles consumption found in later periods.  Reading: a. 王明輝，《青海民和喇家遺址發掘報告》,《考古》2000.12, 第12—28页。 b. 葉茂林，《喇家遺址與飲食文明》，《中國飲食文化》2008，4(2)，45—76。   4. Jiaozi (Dumplings) and the State of Xue (?—327 BC) Jiaozi takes in different forms in Chinese cuisine. The earliest evidence came from a site in the State of Xue of the Warring States period (c.476—221 BC). This lecture uses Xue as the introductory point and unfolds the story of the many states and their finds from the period before the First Emperor unified China.  Reading: a. 薛國故城勘查和墓葬發掘報告《考古學報》1991.4。 b. 印群，《論春秋時期魯東南殉人墓隨葬青銅禮器的特點 —兼談莒、薛文化因素之異同》，《齊魯學刊》2015.3，40—46。  5. Meat and wine and the Xianyang Airport site In 2009, a bowl of meat soup was found in Xi’an. Domesticated pigs, sheep and ox were found in as early as late Neolithic. Boiling was the primary method of cooking. In Xi’an this tomb of the Han dynasty revealed the soup serving, as well as bottle of wine. This lecture illustrates a banquet in association with the many bronze cooking and serving vessels found.  Reading: a.陕西省考古研究院，《西安咸陽國際機場專用高速公路十六國墓發掘簡報》，《文博》2009.4，3—11。 b. 陝西省考古研究所，《漢陽陵》，北京︰文物，2006。  6. Fieldtrip: Sauces and Seasoning Sauces are not commonly found at archaeological sites. Because Hong Kong has a number of locally produced sauce workshops, a fieldtrip to one of them is enriching. The arrangement has to be made in due course. Otherwise, the fieldtrip may be a visit to a relevant museum exhibition in Hong Kong or Shenzhen.  7. Snacks and the early Han-dynasty tombs of Mawangdui, Hunan province When food surplus is sufficient, snacks are desired. At Mawangdui, the tomb of the wife of the regional lord contained bottles of nuts, chestnut, and other food.  Reading: a. 《馬王堆漢墓帛書》，北京︰文物，1980—85。 b. 陳建明，《馬王堆漢墓研究》，長沙︰岳麓書社，2013。  8. Tofu and the Han-dynasty Tomb at Mixian Dahuting, Henan province  Tofu was not preserved in any archaeological site. But the process of making tofu was recorded. At Mixian, the relief paintings found in the tomb illustrate the tofu-making processes in detail, along with other cooking and food preparing pictures. It remains a mystery as to why the people of the Han preserved such scenes in burials. But they provided insightful details about how these people perceived of food in relation to their afterlife.  Reading: a. 河南省文物研究所，《密縣打虎亭漢墓》，北京︰文物，1993。 b. 馮麗麗，《秦漢飲食略考》，《宜春學院學報 》，2010，32(11)，79—81。  9. Bread and the Western Xia Hoard of Inner Mongolia  Bread or bun did not survive well in most archaeological sites. But a hoard of Western Xia in Inner Mongolia revealed several well-preserved pieces. The Inner Asian forms of these finds related them to the Silk Road. In fact, a number of dried food examples came from that part of the world, because the dry weather favoured preservation.  Reading: a. 伊克昭盟文物工作站，《准格爾旗發現西夏窖藏》，《文物》1987.8。 b. 王仁湘，《考古貴州》，電視廣播資源。  10. Tea and the Liao-dynasty tombs of Xuanhua, Hebei province  Tea leaves have always been important in China. The cemetery at Xunhua belonged to a Han family living in the Liao regime. There were many pictures of tea preparation and serving.  Reading: 《宣化遼墓︰1974—1993年考古發掘報告》，北京，文物，2001。  11. Exotic food  Chili, spices, potatoes, and a number of essential ingredients in Chinese cuisines came from abroad at different times. How did they manage to enter an established food culture?   12. Guest lecture  In China, food is a topic inevitably related to health, festivals and rituals. It will be exciting to include a lecture to be given by a specialist in Religious Studies, Chinese Medicine, or Maritime Trade, who has research interests in food. The lecture provides another dimension of looking at Chinese food.  13. Food and rituals  In conclusion, food is indispensable in social lives and rituals. In the examples discussed, food was always found in tombs, closely associated with the desires of nourishment, social engagement, and even hierarchy. Today, what’s the role of food in our ‘rituals’? And how do we shape ‘rituals’ through different food?

title: Language and Practice of Cultural Management
description: The course looks into the practical as well as the critical sides of cultural management, giving students a more elaborated understanding of cultural management, covering several major areas including 1) The cultural and social implication of cultural institution and its dynamic interaction with contemporary society; 2) Mode of governance and operation of different types of cultural institutions; 3) Basic administrative and technical skills in planning and implementing various types of cultural programmes; 4) Professional ethics, social responsibilities and responsiveness to community needs. It intends to help students to build a solid technical as well as intellectual base for further specialized studies in cultural management.

title: Art Institutions in Twentieth-Century China
description: The course examines the correlation between art and institutions in twentieth-century China, aiming to encourage students to think about modern Chinese art through the concept of the artworld. The downfall of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republican China transformed the social and institutional organisation of the production, distribution, and consumption of art as well as the traditional patronage system in modern China. The structural changes conditioned the emergence of formal and informal art institutions that facilitated yet constrained artistic practices, laying the foundation for the development of a modern art world in China. The course looks at the history of modern Chinese art and the formation of different art institutions in the sociocultural and economic context of modern China. Weekly topics are structured chronologically and thematically, which cover a wide range of themes, including art schools, art societies, museums, exhibitions, and art market. Adopting an interdisciplinary approach, the course offers students multi-perspectives to understand the transformation of modern Chinese art and the interactions between artistic practices and society in modern China.
outcome: • Explain the theory of the artworld and history of art institutions in modern China. • Identify and describe the historical background, aesthetics, and social factors reflected in specific artworks. • Identify and interpret the correlation between artistic styles and the institutional organisation. • Reflect upon the roles of art institutions in the process of art creation, production, distribution and consumption.  • Select research materials and develop original research topics on modern Chinese art.

title: Chinese Material Culture
description: (UGED2285 is double-coded with CUMT2004.) This is a cross-disciplinary course straddles the studies of history, anthropology, and sociology from the perspective of material objects. The course intends to achieve two goals: first, it leads students to identify and appreciate the traditional Chinese values, which include the teachings of Confucianism and Daoism, embodied in the many production types pertinent to what we now regard as Chinese; and second, it explains how those various material types ended up being included and translated as the representative categories of Chinese civilization throughout the historical times. The course will begin from the basic by introducing the mainstream material productions from ancient to modern China: jades, antique bronzes, lacquer, ceramics, architecture, silk, as well as grave goods. The discussions instruct students to appreciate these essential elements of Chinese culture from the perspectives of their physical qualities, craftsmanship, and historical values. They are also to encourage students to think about the roles of material objects in shaping cultural, ethnic, and even national identities.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to identify the material and artistic features of some mainstream Chinese artifacts; develop interests in Chinese culture from the perspective of objects; identify key historical sites and remains of pre-modern China; develop acute senses for appreciating traditions and values; develop interests in culture and history; analyze the sources of Chinese heritage and traditions; think critically about historical and other relevant cultural presentations; and get prepared for further trainings in the disciplines of art history, archaeology, anthropology and history.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: What is the present view about Chinese material culture?  Present-day China received huge inheritance from the many groups of people and cultural traditions that existed in antiquity. This session introduce a range of material culture that makes up the broad family of Chinese culture. The most important types include jades, antique bronzes, lacquer, ceramics, and architecture. The definitions given here hope to broaden the scope and include the less-discussed categories of clothing and costumes, sculpture, and grave goods. This overview leads students to consider the many sources of traditional values now embodied in the material culture that we now describe as ‘Chinese’.  2. Jades In China, jades have always been understood to have spiritual power and artistic values. What is the scientific definition of jades? How did Confucius and his contemporaries define the roles of jades? How did their teachings shape the understanding of jades in Chinese society? And what are the present views about jades? This session will respond to this question by giving a review of jade history, usage and craftsmanship.  3. Antique bronzes Among the many treasures inherited from the past, bronzes are core collections that they are always found as representatives of ancient China in modern museums both in China and overseas. This session will describe different categories of bronzes and the motifs found on them in relation to their dates. It will also introduce the imperial collections found in the Kaogu tu, and later on in Xiqing gujian; and explain the values and significance of bronze collections in modern museums.   4. Lacquer Lacquer is a unique production of ancient China. This session introduces the complicated steps involved in its production, and reviews lacquer-using history in China and in other parts of Asia. The discussion leads student to become aware of the broad transmission of the lacquer-using traditions in Asia that shaped a central role for China in antiquity.  5. Sculpture In China, sculptural representation is closely tied with religious practices. This session will introduce the Buddhist sites in Henan and Sichuan, as well as the pictorial representations found in the Daoist temples in Hebei. The session will describe the renewed definition of sculpture in the modern times when the Western artistic values were received.  6. Architecture Architecture forms an essential part of material culture. In China, however, the studies of historical architecture began rather late. This session introduces the classic writings by Liang Sicheng, as well as the renowned Yingcao fasi, the Building Manual composed in the Song period, which founded the standardized Chinese construction works.   7. Silk Silk production began in the late Neolithic period. This session introduces the traditional steps in silk-making and weaving as found in craftsman handbooks published in the Ming period; and discusses how silk as commodity embodies the rich history of cultural exchange between China and the West through trade.  8. Ceramics Ceramics are representative productions of south China. This session introduces the production of the classic kilns of Ge, Yu, Ding, Longquan, and Jingdezhen. This session instructs students to identify the colour, texture, decoration, as well as motifs found on the ceramics produced in different areas. They embody rich aesthetic values deemed appropriate in Confucian classics.  9. Ornaments Chinese ornaments comprise an extended family of motifs that include flowers, birds, figures, beasts, characters, as well as scenes. This session discuss two key groups: plants and dragons. The former was adopted from both nature and religious practices; whereas the latter was acquired through cultural construction over time. This session discusses how the two genres merged along difference courses into what we understand as being Chinese today.   10. Chinese calligraphy and paintings Chinese calligraphy and paintings represent a major aesthetic system that includes the use of ink and brush, writing, as well as imagination particularly defined in Daoist writings. This session introduces the basic concepts of calligraphy and the features found in the classic paintings from the Song to the Qing periods.   11. Grave goods: objects for the deceased  Mingqi is a unique category of items produced in China. It is a group of goods created especially for the burial with the deceased that they are closely connected with the Chinese ideas about ghosts, spirits, and afterlife. This session will review the history of mingqi from as early as the Bronze Age, and look into how this understanding is translated in modern practice.  12. Antique collection and modern consumerism The antiquities of China provide a resourceful base for modern designers and cultural industries. In light of modern consuming practices, Chinese designers, architects, museum workers, historians, and other culture-related professionals fall back on inheritance to seek for ideas to create something new and unique for the country. This session reviews the concerns of relevant practitioners.   13. Conclusion  The concluding session outline the present ideas about material culture and its role in modern society, which is a topic that has become increasingly important in the spheres of anthropology and sociology. This session will combine the discussions on Chinese material culture and the discourse of object studies. This will give students ideas to develop interests in the study of China; and enable them to engage the past with the present.

title: Management of Public and Non-profit Cultural Organization
description: Public and non-profit cultural organizations are positioned in the core part of traditional arts management education. This course aims to equip students with knowledge on the characteristics of public and non-profit cultural organizations as one type of cultural organizations, and mastery of the key management components of public and non-profit cultural organizations, including strategic planning, structural design, human resource management, leadership building, financial planning and fiscal management, marketing cultural products, and the organizations’ internal and external control and performance evaluation. A series of in-class exercises and individual and group projects is designed to develop students’ knowledge and management skills simultaneously.

title: Understanding Chinese Art through Exhibitions
description: (UGED2286 is double-coded with CUMT2006.) The exhibition has become a site of knowledge production and a prominent and diverse part of contemporary culture. Regarding “Chinese art” as a social constructed concept, the course uses “exhibition” as an entry point to engage with issues concerning Chinese art and to explore the role played by exhibitions in the formation of the knowledge of Chinese art. It introduces the current theories and debates on the theory and history of exhibition, and the display methods, examining the changing concept of Chinese art and curatorial practices through detailed analysis of case studies. The first part of the course traces the formation of the concept of “Chinese art” by looking closely at the history of exhibitions on Chinese objects from the late Qing dynasty to the early twentieth century. The second part examines important exhibitions that have shaped our understanding of Chinese art. Structured thematically, the course discusses the curatorial concepts of selective significant international exhibitions on Chinese art, and investigate how scholarly research has been transformed into exhibitions which have shaped our understanding of Chinese art, constructed identity and been deployed for political ends.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:  ·      Explain the theories of exhibition and the changing concepts of Chinese art  ·      Identify and describe the important exhibitions on Chinese art and prominent Chinese art objects. ·      Identify and evaluate the curatorial ideas of important exhibitions on Chinese art. ·      Select research materials and Chinese art objects to develop original research. ·      Design and plan a virtual exhibition based on original research.

title: Curation in Arts and Culture
description: “Curating,” a word that was once only used in museums, now has applications in everything in our lives, ranging from radio station DJs to almost all types of social media content. The popularity of the word reflects the growing importance of assembling, managing and presenting data and collection, a process of gathering information that brings maximum value relevant to different audiences.In this context, this course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to learn about both historical and contemporary examples of how culture is understood through exhibition design and curating. By covering various forms of curatorial traditions, disruptive ideas, and emergent digital practices in the ever-expanding field of curation, this course equips students with the ability to question what they take for granted and reflect on existing issues conducive to different cultures, values and beliefs. By the end of the course, students will be able to critically examine how knowledge is created inside and outside of art institutions and how curation could potentially become public knowledge.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to: • Explain key historical and contemporary examples of exhibition design and curating, relating to a wider local and global context • Examine critical issues concerning ways that different cultures, values and beliefs are represented through curation • Develop skills to critically analyze how knowledge is created inside and outside art institutions • Acquire personal and social competencies to transfer curating into knowledge sharing and act as an active agent in facilitating knowledge engagement  • Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions in the ever-expanding field of curation

title: Introduction to the Art Market
description: The artworld is constructed through a network of individuals and institutions, all of which participate in con-tributing to the wider ecosystem of the global network and marketplace for art. The co-generative or mutu-ally constitutive nature between key players and institutions provides the context and rules for evaluating the aesthetic and economic value of art objects. In recent years, the art market has witnessed tremendous growth, and clusters of new galleries, global art fairs and auction houses have sprung up in cities within both developed and emerging economies, forming an ever-expanding network of art transitions, exhibi-tions, and causing an explosion of cultural activities amid various forms of urbanization. This course aims to provide students with theoretical knowledge and practical skills on how to identify the dynamic roles and activities of key players and institutions in the art market. It begins with an introduction to the history of art market, patronage system and art market logic. The, various practical skills are covered, including art valuation methods, techniques of buying and selling art, and agreements and laws that govern art transactions. In addition to practical skills, this course also encourages students to critically evaluate the complex relationships between the economy, aesthetic values and social behaviors within the global market-place. Special focus will be on emerging technologies and platforms concerning the global online art market.

title: Music, Culture and Outreach
description: It is of crucial significance for cultural practitioners and managers to develop a solid foundation and capability in understanding the nature of music from various perspectives, as well as possessing the competency in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of musical works for the sake of advocating, marketing, coordinating and managing various programmes, events and outreach in music. Through exploring a wide range of music literature from different historical periods in music, the course focuses on three main perspectives:The first perspective focuses on listening and examining the major masterpieces in the history of music from Middle Ages to Modern, in which musical elements and characteristics of major forms and genres will be introduced and analysed. The second perspective is identified by the relationship of music to culture, in which the influence that cultural, social, political and religious events have exerted on music will be discussed. The third perspective focuses on experiencing and examining the approaches of music education in advocating music in the society. Through experiential learning, students will be able to develop basic knowledge and skills for applying the current theories and approaches in music education (e.g. play-based approach, Orff Schulwerk, Dalcroze, Kodaly) to outreach and education in the society.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: 1. Develop a comprehensive understanding of the musical elements which define styles, genres and historical periods of music; 2. Demonstrate cognitive, analytic and critical skills in analysing the musical works of different historical periods; 3. Gain comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the influence that cultural, social, political and religious events have exerted on music; 4. Understand pertinent education theories in music education and their implications on musical enculturation and advocacy; 5. Develop plans of introducing music through outreach activities to children and the general public by creative, play-based and other current music pedagogies such as Orff Schulwerk and Dalcroze.
syllabus: Part I: Basics in Music Appreciation  1. What is “Music Appreciation”?  This session gives an introduction to how to be an ‘educated’ listener’. Major elements and focus of listening in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of music will be introduced.  2. Roles of Music in the Society This session discusses the roles of music in the society and various impacts of music will be discussed. Also, this section investigates how cultural, social, political and religious events have influenced the development of music.  3. Understanding Orchestration  This session uses musical excerpts and examples to illustrate the characteristics and timbre/tone colour of a wide range of orchestral instruments, as well as various concepts on orchestration.   4. Field Trip Field trip to a music institution (e.g. orchestra) will be arranged for students to gain a deeper understanding on the various aspects of performance as well as management of music institutions.  Part II: A Journey to Appreciating Music  5. Music in Middle Ages (500-1400) and Renaissance (1450-1600) This session introduces the main characteristics of Middle Ages and Renaissance music. Major genres and musical styles of the Middle Ages will be discussed, e.g. Gregorian Chant, Mass, Estampe, Rondeau. Featured genres in the Renaissance will also be discussed, e.g. Motet, Mass, Madrigal, Lute Song, Polychoral Motet. Through exploring the musical works of Middle Ages and Renaissance, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  6. Music in the Baroque Period (1600-1750)  This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Baroque music. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. Opera, Solo Concerto, Prelude and Fugue, Cantata, Oratorio, Suite. Through exploring the musical works of Baroque period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  7. Music in the Classical Period (1750-1820) This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Classical Period. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. sonata form, theme and variation, rondo, classical symphony, classical concerto.   8. Music in the Romantic Period (1820-1900)  This session studies the main characteristics of Romantic period. Romantic art songs, operas, programme music, and instrumental works will be introduced and analysed. Through exploring the musical works of Classical period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  9. Modern Music (1900-Present)/Music of Non-Western Cultures This session studies the main characteristics of modern music. For example, expressionism, impressionism, 20th century nationalism, and Jazz music will be introduced and analysed. This session also examines the characteristics, musical styles, genres, instrumentation of music from non-western culture, e.g. music in sub-Saharan Africa, classical music of India, Koto music of Japan. Through exploring music of non-western cultures and the musical works of modern period , the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  Part III: Bringing the Joy of Appreciating Music through Education  10. Current Theories and Practices in Music Education  This session focuses on discussing the current theories, thoughts, and approaches in music education, e.g. Developmentally Appropriate Practice (DAP), Play-Based Approach, Orff Schulwerk, and Dalcroze Approach. The application of these approaches and theories to music appreciation activities in outreach programmes will be discussed.  11. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (I) Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in movement and choreography for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.  12. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (II) Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in singing and chanting, and the application of percussion instruments for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.  13. Presentation and Conclusion

title: Art Institutions in Twentieth-Century China
description: (GENA2372 is double-coded with CUMT2013)The course examines the correlation between art and institutions in twentieth-century China, aiming to encourage students to think about modern Chinese art through the concept of the artworld. The downfall of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republican China transformed the social and institutional organisation of the production, distribution, and consumption of art as well as the traditional patronage system in modern China. The structural changes conditioned the emergence of formal and informal art institutions that facilitated yet constrained artistic practices, laying the foundation for the development of a modern art world in China. The course looks at the history of modern Chinese art and the formation of different art institutions in the sociocultural and economic context of modern China. Weekly topics are structured chronologically and thematically, which cover a wide range of themes, including art schools, art societies, museums, exhibitions, and art market. Adopting an interdisciplinary approach, the course offers students multi-perspectives to understand the transformation of modern Chinese art and the interactions between artistic practices and society in modern China.
outcome: • Explain the theory of the artworld and history of art institutions in modern China • Identify and describe the historical background, aesthetics, and social factors reflected in specific artworks. • Identify and interpret the correlation between artistic styles and the institutional organisation. • Reflect upon the roles of art institutions in the process of art creation, production, distribution and consumption.  • Select research materials and develop original research topics on modern Chinese art

title: Visual Arts Management
description: This course leads students to study various modes and philosophies of visual arts management undertaken in different venues. Aesthetics and art criticisms are critical in directing art interpretation and presentation. Contemporary management of visual arts responds predominantly to the worldwide discussions on modernism as well as various post-modernist writings. In addition, it has to operate in accordance with the prescribed state policy. For this bilateral concern of art management, the course comprises two sections. The first section leads students to study the writings on aesthetics by critics from Plato to Foucault, whose arguments are still valid in inspiring many art exhibitions. The second section discusses the practical concerns and techniques in maximizing the social and economic impacts of art exhibitions and relevant events. Both sections discuss case studies taken from different parts of the world.

title: Performing Arts Management
description: This course discusses the missions, administrations, and strategies of performing art organizations. Since the 1950s, performing art managers have realized the significance of efficient management in achieving popularity and sale. This course will go through the general topics as to how the performing art organizations are administered in national and legal terms; how they solicit funding; how they are operated in terms of ticketing and touring; and how they are strategically promoted for both branding and social benefits.

title: New Media Arts Management
description: This course introduces a new genre in the art discipline that employs electronic and digital devices as the main medium of communication. The course contains three sessions. The first session explains the birth of this set of contemporary art practices in relation to the Dadaist movement of the early twentieth century that opened up new concepts for visual arts. This will be followed by a session that discusses the range of media now commonly adopted in the discipline, including video, photography, computer graphics, webpage, and the Internet. Different set of techniques are involved in these productions, and they often generate quite different social impacts that affect both the producers and the users. Students are instructed to understand both the technological and social aspects of these areas. The last session comprises a series of workshops that lead students to appreciate and comment on the most featured productions. title: Public and Community Art
description: Public art is considered as an important cultural asset of metropolitan cities, closely related to city images and development. Community art serves as a tool for community development, based on the understanding that expression, mastery and communication through the arts powerfully encode cultural values, thus bringing deeper meanings of experience, participation and involvement, sense of belonging to the general public and the community. This course aims to advance students’ understanding of public and community arts by embedding them in the theoretical discussions and critiques of cities and public spaces and practical experiences. It also imparts the knowledge and skills about managing public arts and actualizing community art programs, and discusses the way to support their development responding to the needs.
outcome: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how public and community arts emerged in the context of urban regeneration and community activist movements. Students are encouraged to critically analyze the meanings and social values of public art spaces. In terms of managerial concepts and skills, students will learn how public and community arts are supported by government policies, material resources, infrastructure and training. Students are expected to understand public art commission and reception, to master basic principles of utilizing public art as an urban design strategy, and to apply varying approaches to facilitating community art development, for example, advancing community art education, utilizing the cultural planning approach to assess community based cultural resources and the place-event approach to creating a sense of community attachment.
syllabus: Part I. Understanding Public and Community Art 1. General Introduction This section begins with displaying a range of public and community art cases and presents an introduction to the course. Three issues are covered in this introductory lecture. First, this section provides the conceptual discussions of public space, public art, and their art forms to enable students to understand what public art space and public art is. Second, this section explores the role of artists in public art space and community development. Third, a historical picture of public art is unfolded, which traces its origin, displays its developing process, and takes a glimpse into its enshrined social values.   2. Understanding Public Art Spaces  How should we understand public art spaces and the public nature of public art? This section embeds these issues into the understanding of a city; it then conveys the ideas that public spaces are socially produced and that city forms are imbued with ideologies. Public art stems from an urban setting and then grows through the urban regeneration movement, which comprises several issues, such as urban image, urban form and urban planning as well as their connections with public art space as a form of representational space. Furthermore, this section explores the public nature of public art by examining the process, by which artists derive value from individual creativity in the studios and immense it into the public space.  Tutorial: Discuss the alternative history of public art (Lacy, 1995, 25–28).  3. Public Art: The Monument The monument is an important theoretical perspective to conceptualize public art. This section explains what a “monument” is and investigates its role—whether statue, memorial, or public statue—in upholding a value-laden system of Western society. Issues under examination range from the connection between monument and national identity, the power and representation of public arts, the transformative understanding of public art as a monument, and the contradictions of public art.  Tutorial: Discuss the public nature of public art.  4. Critical Issues of Public Art Spaces Who comprise the “audience” of public arts? What does “intention” mean and what is the “effectiveness” of public art? This section further discusses the theories on critical issues related to public art. This section begins with the discussions of the relevant terms and proceeds to various critical thoughts that challenge the value of public art and question its public nature. Students are expected to be able to analyze public art spaces and public art critically. Tutorial: Develop critical thinking about public art spaces and public art.  5. Public Arts and Community Cultural Development: Theoretical Underpinnings of Community Art This section provides a synopsis of the histories and theoretical issues of community art. The origin of community art is traced to the discourse of William Morris’s call for social reintegration of artists and a revival of art in the 19th century. Theoretical issues include the “popular front” and class consciousness, civil rights and identity politics, as well as cultural democracy and exchange. In addition, this section discusses the definitions of community, the role of community art, and the core purposes of community development.  Tutorial: Discuss the question, “What makes art valuable?”   Part II. Public Art Management  6. Commission and Reception of Public Art Based on the public nature of art, this section analyzes the process of art making, which comprises the elements of audience, context, and meaning. The process includes the following: acquiring cultural approval, arriving in public sites and places, providing visiting experiences with the audience, and generating meanings. Cases of Seattle and New York are used for this study. With regard to art reception, it analyzes the issues of taste, the education of the audience, as well as the relationship of art to society and popular visual culture. In addition, this section also distinguishes performance culture from monumental public art. Tutorial: Distinguish public art from community art.  7. Public Art and Urban Design This section presents an urban design approach to commissioning and making public art. It outlines the principles for creating a city image, which consists of five elements, and discusses their connections to public art. Various forms of public art in association with the urban setting and the mechanism of public art utilization as an urban design strategy are also discussed. Students are guided toward understanding the role of public arts in urban design guidelines. Moreover, we also discussed a set of design principles on the relationship between public art and various urban forms and spatial components, aimed at integrating public art into the urban setting as context and reference is discussed. Tutorial: Conduct design software training.  Assignment: Find a sample of public art (i.e., sculpture) using design principles to assess its location, site, and designs as well as to evaluate its strengths and weaknesses. Write a paper based on the research and use the design software to illustrate the arguments.   8. Government Policies for Public and Community Art Development The relation between power and public and community art is a critical issue in public and community art management. This section discusses the governmental structure that funds and commissions public art, the infrastructure that underpins public art, and the governmental policies that support community art. The selection of commissions and projects is discussed, along with the process of seeking public and professional responses. International and the local Hong Kong contexts are examined to explore how government policies affect public and community art. In the local context, the role of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department in promoting public art in Hong Kong is adopted as a case study. Tutorial: Conduct an in-class test.   9. Public Art in Metropolitan Cities This section analyzes the role of public art in metropolitan cities, especially in the spheres of public transport, public open spaces, and public health system. A number of cases are presented, including forms of public art in the New York Subway system, London Underground and Mass Transit Railway, and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong. The issue of commissioning public arts is revisited in the public art in metropolitan context.  Tutorial: Discuss urban design and public art in Hong Kong.  Part III. Community Art Management 10. Developmental Needs of the Field How can community art development be supported? What do communities need? This section specifies the scope of cultural policies and the policy climate that community artists and community cultural development require. Moreover, this section discusses the material support that community cultural organizations and artists need, including funding supports and internal infrastructure and exchange. Tutorial: Discuss the cultural policies for public art in Hong Kong.  11. From Theory to Practice I: Process to Develop Community Arts From theory to practice, this section offers students a general orientation, which serves as a road map to the community-based art process. Five conceptual territories to advance community-based art as well as requisite techniques to fulfill tasks are introduced in this section, which include the following: 1) contacting people in the community; 2) conducting research on the culture of the community and the people’s perception of their community; 3) taking actions to make art projects; 4) gaining feedbacks from the community; and 5) incorporating these art forms into community art education programs to pass on skills and sustain the impact. The program also includes strategies for planning and organizing community outreach and engagement programs as well as ways to enhance public awareness. Tutorial: Discuss the process of applying theories in the creation of community art in order to practice and initiate the group project with the community.  12. From Theory to Practice II: Key Issues in Community Art Development Based on the holistic picture of the steps to develop community arts, this section focuses on certain key and challenging issues in the process, specifically those on research methods and art making. The section introduces qualitative and quantitative research methods for the project of community art development, and students are expected to learn how to identify survey areas, design survey questionnaires, run group discussions, and map cultural mind-sets and assets. Another key issue is how to make arts and work with artists. An artist will be invited to be the guest speaker to give the lesson. Tutorial: Develop a group project with the community.   13. Review and discussions Students will present their on-going group projects on community art development, and the professor then provides comments and feedbacks on their projects. Key points of this course will also be reviewed in this class.

title: Design Your Exhibition – Curatorial Planning and Practice
description: “Curator” once referred to an expert in keeping collections and making exhibitions, but has been expanded to encompass a hybrid role in innovation and knowledge creation. Today, curators are active agents in social and cultural transformation, taking part in dynamic projects presented by museums, commercial galleries, non-profit art spaces, biennials, art fairs, and many disruptive platforms beyond the field of art that didn’t previously exist. Curators produce knowledge, engage their audience, spark innovation, and constantly challenge the role of “curator” beyond the confines of the status quo across varied institutional settings. This course aims to provide students with hands-on experience in exhibition curation and engages students in a broad spectrum of real-world experiences and professional networking opportunities, aiming to prepare students for future curatorial projects/jobs. It covers topics such as idea conceptualization, proposal writing, pitching, budgeting, contracting, publication, exhibition design, installation and exhibition maintenance. By co-curating an exhibition in a non-profit art space in Hong Kong, students will take part in the various stages of exhibition making. With a focus on exhibition experience, audience engagement, and sociability, this course will train students in the role of being a curator and enable students to develop leadership skills and critically apply knowledge conducive to creative outcomes.
outcome: Upon completing the course, students will be able to: • Explain the key roles of being a curator • Develop skills in the various stages of exhibition making from a broad spectrum of real-world experience and professional networking opportunities • Acquire personal and social competencies to work cooperatively in a team  • Develop critical analysis skills concerning exhibition experiences, audience engagement and sociability • Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions in the ever-expanding field of curation

title: Entrepreneurship in the Creative Industries
description: The concept of “creative industry” was proposed by the Labor Party in the U.K. in 1997. It refers to the activities that are embedded in individuals’ creativities, talents and skills, which have the potential for employment opportunities and economic growth through the exploitation of intellectual properties. Creative industry has become a key area in contemporary cultural policies. This course introduces students to the basic knowledge of managing entrepreneurship, which is a key issue in the creative industries. It comprises three parts. The first part provides a general introduction. The second part discusses the nature of entrepreneurship in creative industries and demonstrates the entrepreneurial process, through which, creative ideas are generated, cultural diffusion is stimulated and innovation processes are carried out. It informs students of the key traits of the creative entrepreneurs and the business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship processes in the creative industries. In the third part, it explores the conducive policy conditions to support and encourage entrepreneurship in creative industries.
outcome: By the end of this course, a student will:  i) Have their understanding being deepened about creative industries and entrepreneurship ii) Value and appreciate entrepreneurial spirits in the creative industries  iii) Develop sets of skills for entrepreneurial practices  iv) Understand the policy conditions for entrepreneurship and acquire consultation skills for the government
syllabus: Part 1: General Introduction  Lecture 1: Creative industries and entrepreneurship: A brief introduction The first lecture in this course will brief the concept of “creative industry” and introduce the key issues of creative industries (e.g., its developmental path, the main traits and its importance to economic growth). Entrepreneurship is a concept key to creative industry development: the creation of new business ventures and the conditions that define corporate venturing will be discussed.  Readings:  CCPR, 2003, 13-26; Harley et. al., 2013, 58-61  Lecture 2: Key issues for stakeholders in the creative industries: A global perspective The development of the creative economy is widely concerned by policymakers, regional and local government and the business community. This section will explore how stakeholders face these issues in creative industries. It will also introduce creative industry development and entrepreneurship in Asia.  Readings:  Ghosh and Malloy, 2011, 12-15; Hui, 2007, 9-29  Part 2: The Entrepreneurial Process  Lecture 3: Cultural diffusion in creative industries Entrepreneurs always face the challenge of transforming their good ideas into entrepreneurial practices. This section will exemplify this process using cases in different creative sectors in Hong Kong. It will explore the issue of “cultural diffusion” in the creative economy, a process, in which, creativity is produced and disseminated among the audience. The affecting factors (e.g., identity, creative product, business process and technology) will be looked into.  Readings:  Desai, 2011, 109-130; Wolf, 1999, 45-61  Lecture 4: Innovation processes Innovation is not equal entrepreneurship, but it could be critical to successful entrepreneurship. This section discusses the scope of innovation, which transforms technical ideas and knowledge into new products or services or production processes. It uses examples of opera concert and film industry to demonstrate the process of innovation.  Readings:  Vickery, 1997, 177-179; Davis and Scase, 2000, 1-22; Hetcher, 2011, 70-80  Lecture 5: Entrepreneurship features of creative entrepreneurs  What are the characteristics of creative entrepreneurs? To be successful in creative entrepreneurship, you need to know yourself first. Creative entrepreneurs display the traits different from managers in traditional industrial sectors; they represent the new knowledge workers with creative minds and risk taking spirits. Cases from music industry and film industry will be used to illustrate the issues.  Readings:  Malloy, 2011, 15-18; Glick, 2008, 73-80  Lecture 6: Exploring business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship  Creative products are delivered on two levels: artists and creative entrepreneurs on the one level; and the state and state entrepreneurship on the other level. title: Curating and Organising Arts Festival
description: With a global growing interest in organizing grand scale arts and cultural activities to attract local and overseas audience, arts festivals have become popular urban cultural events for cultural development and for building the reputation of a city. Curating and managing cultural festival is subsequently an important area of studies in cultural management. Curating and organizing arts festival is a complex process that requires creative programming, skillful execution and careful financial control. This course not only studies the mode of operations of various types of cultural festivals, including festivals of performing arts, visual arts, film, literary arts and community festive celebration, but also introduces to students the basic skills and knowledge of curating and organizing arts festivals, with references to local and overseas examples.
outcome: - Understand the operation format, management process in organizing various types of cultural festivals; - Have the ability to curate and coordinate programmes within a specific arts/cultural festival; - Learn the supporting skills for successful implementation of arts/cultural festival, including publicity, marketing, public safety, security and finance control; - Equip students with the critical skills to review and evaluate the success and failure of a major cultural event.
syllabus: 1. Cultural Festival: an introduction  This session studies the history, social functions and basic modes of operation of cultural festivals, with examples from Hong Kong and fromvarious parts of the world.  2. Various types of festivals and their distinctive characters  This session introduces various types of arts festival, from festivals focusing on specific media, grand scale multi-disciplinary festivals, to community based religious/celebrative events, with emphasis on studying their own distinctive characteristics and special technical requirements.  3. Planning cultural festival 1:  This session focuses on programme planning and coordination, as well as resource management within the institutional and community context.  4. Planning festival 2:  This session deals with the planning of setting up an operation framework, allocation of manpower, design of the technical support and working out an operational schedule for a major arts festival.  5. Planning festival 3:  Funding is an essential part of organizing cultural festivals. This session studies the various ways to seek public and private fund, and ways to do financial planning and to exercise financial control over the running of projects.  6. Planning festival 4:  In addition to curating and implementing programmes, a successful festival also includes much supporting activities, ranging from marketing to educational events. This session focuses on the studies of these supplementary activities in order to get the best results for an arts event.  7. Presentation and discussion Students are asked to form groups to work on proposals for an arts festival. Students are to do their representations at class, and engage in discussion after the presentations.  8. Curation and programming This session studies the curation of festival programmes with references to local cultural strength and needs, the use of available resources, as well as a study of the global trends in arts festival.  9. Execution and crisis management This session studies the security measure for major cultural events, and preparations required for unexpected incidents and crisis.   10. Case studies Using the Hong Kong Arts Festival and Hong Kong Film Festival for case studies, this session studies the actual implementation of cultural festivals within the specific social, cultural and financial context of Hong Kong.  11. Evaluation and research The success of a festival depends heavily on responses from the audience, the press and the public, this session studies the application of marketing strategies and its consequent results, and ways to make meaningful evaluation for future development.  12. Critical issues relating to arts festival As arts and cultural festivals become increasingly prolific, its social and cultural impacts are not to be underestimated. This session takes on a critical review of the impacts, the pro and con of organizing arts festivals, as well as possible alternatives.  13. Review and discussion This session reviews the entire course and engages students in an over-all discussion.
