title: Interpreting Chinese Antiquities
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT4101 Special Topics in Cultural Management (Heritage, Archaeology and Interpretation theme)
description: From the perspective of archaeology, this course is tailored to cross disciplinary boundaries between heritage and contemporary issues. The world of ancient China is a rich source of inspirations for museum work; tourism; films and documentary; literature; designs; and even commercial productions. Yet misinterpretations over Chinese history have led to problematic descriptions of heritage and archaeological sites. Indeed, there have not been many discussions of Chinese historical past independent of texts, and this course intends to fill up the lacuna. Taking ancient and medieval China as subjects, this course leads student to appreciate Chinese arts and archaeological finds from between the Neolithic and the 13th century. The course urges students to develop acute senses in reading and writing about heritage for contemporary needs.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to identify key historical sites and remains of pre-modern China; analyze the roles and management of heritage or its relevant institutions; think critically about historical exhibitions and other cultural events; develop acute senses for appreciating traditions and values; develop interests in culture and history; and get prepared for career related to management of heritage and arts industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Why is material culture? What is heritage?  What is the difference between history and archaeology? Why should we pay attention to material objects? This session introduces the discipline of archaeology and describes its application in China. It defines what we speak of Chinese heritage from the perspective of material remains.   2. Neolithic China: The Rise of Numerous Jade-using Sources  As of 2014, more than 10 different Neolithic cultures have been identified in China. To what extent have we moved beyond the old understanding about Yangshao and Longshan cultures in central China? What do the new finds tell us about China during the Neolithic times (c.5000—c.2000 BC). And how do they fit into the unified picture of what we call ‘China’ today.   3. The Shang period: the Dawn of Civilization  There are some textual descriptions about the Shang dynasty. But its archaeological boundaries are subject to debates. This session introduces the key Shang sites in Henan, as well as their contemporary sites found in Sichuan, Hunan, and other Chinese provinces. It leads student to pay attention to the interpretation presented in most Chinese museum—all Bronze Age cultures were re-think the connections between the early Bronze Age and the present.   4. Western Zhou: The Early Development of Cultural Borrowings Western Zhou is understood as one of the most esteemed periods in antiquity. This session looks into the archaeological finds from the 10th to 8th century BC and discusses what bronzes tell us about the several important political decisions the Zhou courts made to consolidate sovereignty. One key policy that the Zhou founders implemented was adaptation to various cultural streams collected from the preceding Shang and other neighbouring groups. This was an unknown yet profoundly important aspect of the Zhou that prepared it for taking the lead of what we today call ‘Chinese’ civilization.   5. Eastern Zhou: The Age of Conformity The flourishing workshops of bronze-casting, lacquers, pottery, and textiles from the Eastern Zhou period provide a vast number of important archaeological finds. This session introduces some key sites, which include Sanmengxia and Leigudun. From them we will discuss the significance of material culture in forming shared heritage roots.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 45—63.  6. Han I: Burial Culture The Han dynasty is a promising period with many textual records and archaeological finds. This first session looks into the Han tomb structure and burial goods, which present some interesting patterns in the religious ideas and practices of the period.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  7. Han II: the Silk Road Connections with the West were well-formed under the Han regime. This session looks at the finds from the Silk Road, which continued to be in use throughout the Han and its following centuries. This session reviews the finds from the Silk Road and discusses their significance for both the intellectual and public sphere in the present times.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  8. Northern & Southern Dynasties: Buddhism in China Buddhism began to appear in China from the Han times, and became vastly important throughout the divided Northern and Southern dynasties. This session introduces the key caves of Buddhist sculpture and discusses the impacts of Buddhist ideas on later Chinese material creations. In particular, Buddhism helped develop a range of ornamental features unprecedentedly formed in the context of China; yet those features have become central in the presentation of Chinese heritage today.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 99—129  9. Tang Dynasty: The Cosmopolitan Cities  This session focuses on the settlement finds from the Tang period. Little is known about ancient Chinese cities or settlement sites, which were prone to destruction. This session leads students to reflect on the urban life in Metropolitan Tang, which was benefited from the access to various exotic goods acquired through the Silk Road.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 131—161.  10. Song I: Antiquarianism and Imperial Collections of Arts The Song dynasty was the age of the studies of antiquities. This lecture introduces the early catalogues of imperial collections that developed the sense of shared inheritance from the ninth century.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 163—205.  11. Song II: Mural Paintings  Mural paintings are important finds from the tombs of the Song period. They usually represent the tomb owners in household quarters, engaged in various activities. More importantly, the neighbouring Qidan and Jin peoples also copied such tradition. This session leads student to discuss the importance in the exchange of burial practices and ideas.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 163—205.  12. Guest lecture/field trip, venue to be decided.  This session will bring some fresh air to the classroom by taking students to look at modern presentation of Chinese material culture. The permanent gallery of the Hong Kong Art Museum will be a good choice. But it depends on the range of exhibitions available during the teaching period. If possible, a trip to visit the site in Guangzhou or Shenzhen will produce constructive impression about modern understanding of China past.   13. Conclusion and discussions of final papers.  This session summarizes the key issues collected from the above lectures. This is hoped to open up discussions for students to review the various sources of traditions that were gathered to form the core of Chinese civilization.

title: Museum Studies
requirements: Not for students who have taken ANTH4720 or HIST5514
description: Museums have multiple roles in a society. They are academic institutes and public arenas for education. In the broad term, they represent national culture and communal heritage. This course leads students to understand museum exhibitions and management within social contexts. The lectures respond to the following issues:1. What are the functions and achievements of museum activities?2. In what ways can we understand and learn from an exhibition? What are the essential elements of museum catalogues and cultural writing?3. How do museum workers balance both marketing and social needs?4. In what ways can we participate in the operation of a museum?The course draws discussions from both the perspectives of museum workers and visitors. Some current issues concerning the roles of museums are also covered.

title: Integrated Studies in Cultural Management
description: This course is continuation of CUMT1001, Introduction to Cultural Management, and looks at cultural management from the macro perspective. Successful culture managers work to maintain healthy balance between culture and its relevant fields of interests, which sometimes could turn harmful or beneficial to the growth and development of the corresponding cultural area. The first session discusses the mutual dependence between culture and various areas, which include laws, economy, community, national interests, and art practitioners. In practice, cultural managers usually have to conform to the values and ethnics of the corresponding countries. For that reason, the second session will look at the approach taken in a few remarkable examples, which Taiwan, China, Singapore, South Korea, U.K., and the U.S.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to explain different national and social concerns for preserving culture; to identify the legal and ethnic issues relevant to cultural productions; to identify marketing strategies in cultural promotion; to evaluate the measures for maximizing the input of art practitioners; and to describe the various successful cultural schemes implemented in overseas countries.
syllabus: Section I: Culture in Context   1. Culture & States The growth of cultural industries is strongly related to political environment and state policy. This lecture discusses the tension and mutual expectations between cultural workers and politicians. It will use the experience of the European Union and the US as examples.   2. Culture & Laws Over the last few decades, there were a number of remarkable disputes over international art transactions and copy rights. Given the growing size of the art market, knowledge about the previous cases is essential. This lecture takes the examples taken from the US for discussions.   3. Culture & UNESCO UNESCO is arguably a rising new power in forming a standard for evaluating cultural heritage of different nations. This lecture discusses the roles of UNESCO and its work in different cultural disciplines. National disputes over ownership of World Heritage sites will be bought up.   4. Culture & Community Nowadays many nations and countries perceive culture and heritage as means to empower developing communities. This lecture discusses the conservation of indigenous or minorities cultures, and its impacts on the majority population of the same community.   5. Culture & Marketing  Culture and business are often taken as two contrasting disciplines. One of the key issues in cultural management is to develop cultural audience with both education and economic concerns. Religious sectors are a growing body of cultural venues for tourism and heritage management. This lecture discusses the debated concerns about conducting marketing or business-driven strategies in cultural and religious areas.   Section II: Case Studies 6. Cultural Management in Taiwan Taiwan provides an excellent example to demonstrate the top-down organization of heritage sites. This lecture reviews a series of campaigns launched in Taiwan during the past twenty years, and discusses the reasons that may have contributed to engage the mass of Taiwan into different aspects of cultural industries.   7. Cultural Management in China China represents many upcoming opportunities in cultural management. This lecture reviews some recent moves: rapid establishment of museums, growing number of commercial galleries and auction houses, rise of new Confucian schools, introduction of university degrees in cultural management, etc. The lecture discusses the consuming force underneath the cultural growth in the Mainland.   8. Cultural Management in Singapore During the last two decades, the government of Singapore invested heavily on constructing cultural venues for both national and economic purposes. This lecture gives an overview of their establishment and invites students to reflect on the opportunities found in other areas of Asia.   9. Cultural Management in South Korea This lecture discusses the contemporary cultural policies undertaken in South Korea. During the last decade, South Korea featured an economic miracle in Asia by rejuvenating the distressed financial market with cultural developments, which included the film industry, heritage protection, publication, and cultural tourism.   10. Cultural Management in UK The United Kingdom was one of the earliest countries that invested heavily on promotion of cultural and arts events. This lecture gives a short history of the early developments made in the UK after the Second World War, and discusses the recent campaigns undertaken to break the boundaries between high arts and popular culture.   11. Cultural Management in USA The United States distinguishes herself from all other countries by boosting the absence of a ministry for arts and culture, yet artists and cultural workers receive due respects for their contributions. This lecture looks at the case of the US and examines her success in cultural management.   12. Group presentation This lecture is taken as a mock symposium for students to present their group projects and make comments on those by their peers. The presentation will be evaluated against the clarity and thoughts over the approved topics.   13. Conclusion: What is the best for Hong Kong?  This last session will summarize the topics covered throughout the course. Hong Kong is facing the challenge that many aspects of cultural developments in relation to urban planning, legislation, economy, national identity, and education are all pending. This lecture is an open discussion for students to brainstorm the possible approaches that Hong Kong could take in years to come.

title: Culture-led City Development
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the culture-led city development phenomenon and equip them with the protocols for execution and practice. It comprises three blocks: Block 1 unfolds an overall picture of the phenomenon, introduces the related concepts, displays the disciplinary foundation of this topic, traces its history, and discusses the rationales and developing tendency. Block 2 studies the urban sociological and economic approaches employed in developing the theoretical foundation, highlighting a transition in capitalist production mode and urban governance upheld by public-private partnership modes. Criticisms are also presented to complete a dialectic mindset of this phenomenon. With a strong practical dimension, Block 3 teaches students various methods to make consultancy and policy recommendations for culture-led urban development projects. A variety of practices that constitute the culture-led strategy are discussed, such as how to plan for a creative city and cultural facilities, how to boost creative industries and develop cultural quarters and creative clusters, as well as how to revitalize historic quarters.

title: Archaeology and Modern Applications
description: Archaeology is an intriguing topic. In CUMT3009 Interpreting Chinese Antiquities, students are taught the essential contents and arguments in each Chinese archaeological period. At this advanced level, students are led to analyze the presentation of Chinese archaeological materials in different modern forms, which are namely, movies, novels, documentary films, museum displays, auction houses, and antique shops. Each class picks up a representative topic and a form of modern expression for discussions. Students of this course are required to have knowledge in Chinese archaeology, because the discussions are carried out in seminar forms, in which their inputs are required. The course gets students to apply the designs and innovations of ancient China to areas, which they may find interests that will eventually get in touch with the wide public.

title: Art and Propaganda
description: The course studies the history, theories and techniques of organizing cultural activities for social and political causes. It investigates the relationship between cultural expressions and the infrastructure of power, and the application of arts and culture for social, political actions, covering such major movements from the avant-garde of the 19th Century, the USSR and the Chinese propaganda movements, to the arts for civil right movements since 1960s. Case studies of similar movements in Hong Kong will also be included. The final part of the course will introduce to students the operational and managerial skill required for organizing such cultural activities.
outcome: Students are expected to understand the historical background of the employment of arts for propaganda and other social, political and economic purposes and to gain the knowledge and critical ability to analysis the social manipulation being undertaken. It also introduces the movement of arts for social actions and the basic technique and sensibility required for organizing these activities.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: arts and the infrastructure of power and arts This session gives introduction to the course content, and a general study of the social production of arts and its relationship with the infrastructure of power, using examples from primitive to contemporary societies.  2. History of Propaganda: Power of arts as political and social expression This session studies artistic expression and its relationship between the Church, monarchy and the merchant class during the Medieval, Renaissance and the 17th Century in Netherlands and France in order to reveal the relationship between patronages and artistic creation as well as their impacts on the mediation of arts.  3. The Grand Utopia: propagandas of the Communist and the Fascist This session studies some of the grandest cultural campaigns organized by the Communists and Fascists for propagandas in the early 20th Century, focusing on the aesthetic, techniques and the philosophies behind these grand projects.  4. Arts for social actions in China This session studies the application of arts for social causes, starting off with the promotion of Kathe Kollwitz by Lu Shen, the woodcut movement, the comics during the 1930s and 40s, the aesthetic of the Chinese Revolution and moving onto the cultural actions by Chinese contemporary arts groups during the 1980s.  5. Propaganda, persuasion and consumption The development of a consumption oriented society relies heavily on advertising and various forms of persuasion. The application of the technique is not only widely employed, but is regarded for any success in not only market promotion, but also in politics and many other matters. This session studies the impact of propaganda in contemporary consumer society, which is strongly dominated by mass media.  6. Social activist arts since 1960s: toward the community Since the civil right movement in the 1960s, cultural workers in the West become increasingly active in utilizing arts for social and political critiques. Frequently such critiques find their expression in community art. This session studies the concepts and approaches of community arts, which has experienced a dramatic growth since the 1960s.  7. Arts for social actions in Hong Kong Tracing back to the local political comic and woodcut during the 1930s and 40s, this session studies the use of arts for social actions, looking at the formats of expression and strategies employed by organizations and alternative activist groups in Hong Kong during the 20th Century.  8. New civil right movement in Hong Kong The dismantling of Star Ferry Pier not only marks a new chapter in heritage conservation, but also triggers a new movement in which cultural workers are actively engaged in social activism. Arts are frequently used as instruments for propagandas and for the nurturing a sense of cultural identity at grass-root level. This session will focus on this phenomenon and its implications to the cultural development of Hong Kong.   9. Practices: Organizing cultural activist actions This session informs student of the use of icons and other technical presentational tools, basic organizational format, operational requirement and managerial needs for organizing cultural activist actions in Hong Kong.  10. Case studies I: Objects, expressive means and operation format  This session focuses on the various means for artistic expression in social action, examples of objects recreated, and the format of operation of cultural activist groups.   11. Field Trip: Managerial Case studies II  This session mainly studies the philosophy, operational model and programmes of arts for social improvements, which are active in working with the underprivileged.  12. Theories, conflict and ethical issues The employment of arts for social and political calls generates numerous debates over the concepts and ethics behind such practices. This session discusses the various views and debates within the field concerning the formats of practices, and investigates some of the ethical issues relating to it.  13. Discussion and review

title: Advanced Museum Studies
description: This course picks up topics, which cannot be fully covered in CUMT4007 Museum Studies, but are essential for students pursuing careers in the area of museum and exhibition planning. This course is an advanced version, because it will touch on debated issues regarding museums. It focuses on installation, display, and site management. The purposes of the course may be summarized as follows: 1. What are the various display methods in museums? What are the concerns involved in selecting the ‘right’ ones? 2. How are museum workers (non-curatorial) trained? 3. What are the essential facilities a museum is expected to have? Why? 4. What is the role of museum in the contemporary arts, which is the area of debate regarding its significance and curatorship? The course develops students’ awareness towards global developments in world-class museums, so that they are equipped with skills and knowledge necessary for long-term competition in museums or other cultural institutions.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Analyze exhibition display methods and theories.  2. Think critically about display and social concerns.  3. Clarify the roles and potentials of museum workers.  4. Get prepared for career related to management of museums and cultural industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: the Unseen Impacts of Museums  Museums make impacts in our societies in many ways, but they are usually gone unnoticed, almost unseen. What are the popular ways taken to measure the impacts of museums? And how useful (and meaningful) are they?  Readings: a. Paulus, Odile. "Measuring Museum Performance: A Study of Museums in France and the United States." International Journal of Arts Management 6, no. 1 (October 1, 2003): 50-63. b. Jacobsen, John W. Measuring museum impact and performance theory and practice (Chapters 2&3). Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield, 2016. PART I Display and Installation 2. Oral Histories I Not everything in the museum is tangible. In many cases, the objects are reminders of something unheard, unseen, or even almost forgotten. Oral histories are a common way to preserve the dying records. This lecture introduces the practice of building oral history records, and get students to develop their set of questions to preserve extinguishing cultural practices or knowledge.  Reading: a. Barnes, Lindsey; Guise, Kim. "World War Words: The Creation of a World War II–Specific Vocabulary for the Oral History Collection at The National WWII Museum." The Oral History Review 40, no. 1 (2013): 126-34. b. Chew, R. "Collected stories - The rise of oral history in museum exhibitions." Museum News 81, no. 6 (Nov. & dec. 2002): 30-37.   3. Oral Histories II  With audio and written records readily made, how do we put them in the museum setting? This lecture discusses various possibilities and gets students to develop the rationale of their selections through debates and discussions.  Reading: a. Jones, Sian. "Oral History and Museum Education." Oral History 12, no. 2 (October 1, 1984): 68-71. b. Green, Anna. "Returning History to the Community: Oral History in a Museum Setting." The Oral History Review 24, no. 2 (December 1, 1997): 53-72. 4. Sound I: Installation of Performance If the intangible cultural heritage is something as abstract as live performance, the elements of living people inputs are unavoidable. The practices and theories regarding the staging of a live show in the museum setting are hinged on the issue of authenticity. How much control does a curator have over the accuracy of the performance?  Reading: a. Pollock, Della, ed. Exceptional spaces: essays in performance and history (Chapter 1&2). Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1998. b. Niblett, Hannah; Allison, Jennifer. "Performance as interpretation: a museum studies perspective." Sound II: Installation of Music  Musical instruments are valuable museum objects, because they embodied the appreciation of music and the meticulous knowledge in physics and mathematics too. In a gallery as quiet as in a museum, how do we deliver or reconstruct ‘music’ for present-day enjoyment?  Readings: Gillespie, Kirsty. "Musical Landscapes of Lihir: Exploring performance and place in a museum exhibition." Perfect Beat 17, no. 1 (2016): 9-24. PART II Auxiliary devices 6. Use of Videos  Showing a clip in the middle of the exhibition is a common practice. What are the conventions in so doing? What are the advantages and limits of applying animations and other digital devices?  Reading: a. George, Judith; Stevenson, Anne. "Structured video recall: a museum application." Learning, Culture and Social Interaction 5 (June 2015): 54-65. 7. Use of Dioramas  Dioramas are most useful in the area of Natural Science, because the extinguished animals and plants are best represented through live reconstructions. Historical museums often employ diorama to highlight the visiting experience.  Reading: a. Knutson, Karen; Lyon, Mandela ; Crowley, Kevin ; Giarratani, Lauren. "Flexible Interventions to Increase Family Engagement at Natural History Museum Dioramas." Curator: The Museum Journal 59, no. 4 (October 2016): 339-52. b. Use of Miscellaneous Objects  Not all objects are substantial or significant enough to be regarded as attractive. In fact, a number of museums nowadays are overflowed with objects of low historical values. title: Special Topics in Antiquities and Heritage Management
description: Cultural Management covers a broad range of inter-disciplinary topics, which include art history, archaeology, visual and material cultures, museum studies, as well as heritage conservation and management. The instructor is to design lectures and tutorials around a special topic relevant to the international issues of Cultural Management. The course is set at a senior level that leads students to apply and think critically of the humanity subjects in relation to contemporary global and ideological concerns.

title: Research Project
description: Students are required to take either this course or “CUMT4103 Internship” to fulfill the capstone course requirements of the Programme. In this course, students are expected to be able to integrate the knowledge and skills that they learnt into a research project. This course has two specific objectives. First, it aims to allow the students to experience completing a coherent research project either by participating in faculty-directed projects as a research group member or conducting independent research under supervision. Second, it will help students develop the preliminary idea of applying theories to answering research questions. This can be done by adopting a constructivist approach with cultural theories to account for a certain phenomenon pertinent to cultural management, or by identifying resolutions based on positive social science theories for cultural management. A faculty member will be assigned based on the student’s area of interest for the research project.
outcome: The students are expected to develop a preliminary perception of academic or applied research, and understand the key steps of research, which include identifying and reviewing the key literature, developing a topic and focus for the research project, and mastering basic methods for data collection, analysis, and application of theories. The process of completing a coherent research will enable students to enrich research skills, such as applying theories, identifying problems, and conducting data collection and analysis.
syllabus: The students will work closely with their supervisor, starting from the second semester of year 3. In the middle of the semester, the students will submit their proposals, which should include literature review, research topic/focus, research question/problem identification, and research design. The key literature of the specialized area should also be identified. The students will be required to prepare and to have an annotated bibliography approved by the supervisor. The literature review should include the mainstream knowledge for doing cultural management in a specialized area, the nature of the management process, and the political, economic, and organizational contexts, in which cultural management is done.  A research topic or focus will be developed based on the observation and interest of the students. The students should seek the advice of the supervisor in deciding the topic or focus, and in doing the succeeding research design. Materials covered under research design include problem identification, hypothesis generation, and major issue and concept. The supervisor will also advise students about the basic qualitative and quantitative research methods, such as statistical methods, interview, and participatory observation, appropriate to developing a conceptual framework. Alternatively, students may identify a social phenomenon pertinent to cultural management or a cultural phenomenon represented by artistic or intellectual works. Students will be encouraged to apply computer-programming techniques covered in related courses.  Students who participate in faculty directed research projects may have the opportunity to avail of partial or full funding for their research and field trips depending on the funding situation. Their work should contribute to the research projects of their supervisors. The students will be advised on how to fulfill the required research tasks and improve their academic writing techniques.  This research project will lead to the completion of a thesis or its equivalent, and further studies at the graduate level. Part of the final product will be a presentation on the research project open to the university. The date for presentation is subject to future arrangements.

title: Internship
description: Students are required to take either this course or “CUMT4102 Research Project” to fulfill the capstone course requirements of the Programme. This course has two specific objectives. First, it aims to assist the students’ understanding of the way that cultural organizations or institutions operate. Students will acquire the chance to observe the organization’s administrative structure with regard to the external policy environment, its strategies for development, partnership with other organizations, the management styles, approaches and methods and decision-making procedures. Second, it will allow students to gain the experiences through the transition from classroom learning to in-practice learning. Students are expected to reflect their learned knowledge with the live cases during the intern and apply professional norms to assess the functionalities and performances of the organization. Recommendations for improvements based on identified challenges and problems that the organization faces will be included into their final reports. A faculty member will be assigned based on the student’s area of interest for the internship.
outcome: The internship will prepare students with the direction of career development in cultural management related areas. Upon completion of this internship course, students will have acquired first-person work experiences in his or her interested aspects of cultural management. Students will also deepen the understanding of the classroom knowledge with self-reflection and develop hand-on skills by applying the knowledge to administrative practices.
syllabus: The internship is typically taken by BA degree students within a cultural agency or organization during the summer vacation period at the end of the third year. The duration of the internship is six to eight weeks and it is normally full-time work (240-320 hours), subject to the agreement with the corresponding party. There might be exceptional cases in which students are engaged in part-time internship programmes held during the academic year because of the scheduling of specific arts projects. During the internship, students are expected to maximize the opportunities to access the staff, board meetings, internal and cross-organizational communications, in order to develop the understanding of the operation of the organization through participatory observation. To enhance on-job professional experience, the students are expected to complete professional management tasks independently or as a member of the agency’s management team with maximized exposure to the entire management process. The students’ internship will be largely in the charge of a field supervisor in the agency. It is important to have adequate on-job supervision that clarifies the policies and job requirements. The student’s supervisor in the Programme will provide advices regarding how to prepare the students for the working environment, carry out on-site observations, and write the final report. The Programme endorses the students’ full-time/part-time internships to fulfill the requirement for the BA degree.   List of available organizations will be announced and interviews arranged normally three to four months prior to actual participation of internship, Students are required to identify three options of organizations, with advices from the internship panel. Arrangement will be made for interviews and the final decisions are to be made by the organizations.  Option is opened for students to suggest organizations that are not of the list provided by the Programme. The suggested organizations must meet the following criteria: 1) Confirmed interest in offering internship; 2) Established organization with proper operational office, full time staff and creditable reputation; 3) Could provide a safe and proper learning/working environment; 4) No possible conflict of interest or personal linkage that might affect the final assessment. Based on the above criteria, the internship panel would make decision regarding the inclusion of the organizations into the internship programme.   Students are urged to timely hand in copies of documentary outputs, if any, of the intern employment, or reports prepared as a part of their internship experience. Arrangement for discussions with their Programme supervisors regarding the internship experience and critiques is encouraged. Students’ performance during the intern should be assessed by their field supervisors. A reviewing letter from the supervisor should be submitted, which contributes to the students’ final grades. In addition to the field supervisors’ assessment, students’ final report and a presentation open to the university are required and will be graded.  In case the student prefers academic pursuit or has tried and failed to obtain an internship, the student may consider conducting an individual research project or participating in faculty-directed research projects as specified in “CUMT4102 Research Project.”

title: Special Topics in Cultural Institutions and Curation
description: The B.A. in Cultural Management Programme offers different special topic courses in cultural management relevant to the current academic interest and concern, in accordance with the three concentrations of the programme. The course Special Topics in Cultural Management: Cultural Institutions and Curation is designed in alignment with the objectives of the concentration “Cultural Institutions and Curation”, covering a broad range of interdisciplinary topics in visual arts, music, performing arts, new media arts, history, heritage, museum, public policy, festivals, as well as cultural globalization. The instructor will design the lectures and tutorials around a special topic relating to the significant international or local issues of Cultural Management. Set as a senior level course within the curriculum, this course aims at advancing students’ knowledge in cultural institutions and curation, as well as sharpening students’ critical thinking in humanity subjects in relation to contemporary global concerns in Cultural Management.

title: Special Topic in Cultural and Creative Industries
description: In recent years, the rapid development of cultural and creative industries has changed the way cultural products are created, produced and distributed. Cultural and creative industries, from theater and fashion to social media and game design, underscore how contemporary societies adopt intellectual and creative approaches to gain economic and symbolic competitiveness. Alongside technological innovations, the creative sector also plays a role in driving global economic transformation, offering government agencies and entrepreneurs new strategies to produce creative experiences not anticipated in the past. This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in cultural and creative industries. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how various sectors within the cultural and creative industries inform a variety of theories and practices. By covering multiple creative and entrepreneurial strategies in the ever-expanding field of cultural and creative industries, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on the current phenomenon and create projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.
outcome: Explain key historical and contemporary examples of the cultural and creative industries, relating to a wider local and global context   Examine critical issues concerning the way different cultural and economic models impact the cultural and creative industries   Develop skills to critically analyze the relationship between culture, society and the economy   Acquire personal and social competencies relating to the cultural and creative industries, and act as an active agent in producing creative projects   Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within the cultural and creative industries
